unnormalised: So, my journey through the academic jungle – oh boy, where do I even begin? Let’s just say it involved a lot of caffeine, questionable instant noodles, and the unwavering belief that somehow, someway, I’d emerge victorious with that coveted piece of paper. And a serious neck problem from hunching over textbooks, maybe.
normalised: So, my journey through the academic jungle – oh boy, where do I even begin? Let's just say it involved a lot of caffeine, questionable instant noodles, and the unwavering belief that somehow, someway, I'd emerge victorious with that coveted piece of paper. And a serious neck problem from hunching over textbooks, maybe.

unnormalised: First up, we have the legendary Class 10 certificate. Ah, the sweet taste of securing 75%. My parents celebrated like I'd discovered a cure for the common cold. Suddenly, I was being compared to Einstein – before they remembered I once tried to microwave a spoon. Good times. It's framed on the wall even now, a constant reminder of the simpler days when quadratic equations were my biggest problem. Little did I know!
normalised: First up, we have the legendary Class ten certificate. Ah, the sweet taste of securing seventy five percent. My parents celebrated like I'd discovered a cure for the common cold. Suddenly, I was being compared to Einstein – before they remembered I once tried to microwave a spoon. Good times. It's framed on the wall even now, a constant reminder of the simpler days when quadratic equations were my biggest problem. Little did I know!

unnormalised: Then came the beast that is Class 12. The percentage target went up to 85%, it's the unspoken Indian parental law, I swear. Suddenly, I was expected to become an IITian, a doctor, or at least a moderately successful engineer. Pressure? What pressure? I just needed to get 90% in Physics, Chemistry, Maths, English, and Computer Science. Easy peasy, lemon squeezy! (Spoiler alert: It wasn't.) I ended up with something closer to 80%, which, surprisingly, didn't result in disownment. A minor miracle, really.
normalised: Then came the beast that is Class twelve. The percentage target went up to eighty five percent, it's the unspoken Indian parental law, I swear. Suddenly, I was expected to become an I-I-T-ian, a doctor, or at least a moderately successful engineer. Pressure? What pressure? I just needed to get ninety percent in Physics, Chemistry, Maths, English, and Computer Science. Easy peasy, lemon squeezy! (Spoiler alert: It wasn't.) I ended up with something closer to eighty percent, which, surprisingly, didn't result in disownment. A minor miracle, really.

unnormalised: Next, the JEE Main. This was the exam that determined whether I was worthy of being an engineer or destined to live under a bridge. Let's just say I 'attempted' it. Got a rank of somewhere around 2,00,000. Bridge underpass it is! Okay, not really, but the look on my parents' faces was almost as bad. The consolation prize? A 'prestigious' degree from a private engineering college.
normalised: Next, the J-E-E Main. This was the exam that determined whether I was worthy of being an engineer or destined to live under a bridge. Let's just say I 'attempted' it. Got a rank of somewhere around two hundred thousand. Bridge underpass it is! Okay, not really, but the look on my parents' faces was almost as bad. The consolation prize? A 'prestigious' degree from a private engineering college.

unnormalised: Ah, B.Tech from VITS, or as I lovingly referred to it, "The Land of Missed Opportunities." Four long years of coding nightmares, lab experiments that went horribly wrong, and the constant fear of failing. I did emerge with a degree (60%, thank you very much), a slightly warped sense of humor, and the ability to debug code with my eyes closed and one hand tied behind my back. Sort of.
normalised: Ah, B-Tech from V-I-T-S, or as I lovingly referred to it, "The Land of Missed Opportunities." Four long years of coding nightmares, lab experiments that went horribly wrong, and the constant fear of failing. I did emerge with a degree (sixty percent, thank you very much), a slightly warped sense of humor, and the ability to debug code with my eyes closed and one hand tied behind my back. Sort of.

unnormalised: And then, because I hadn't suffered enough, I decided to prepone my MBA from IIM-C. Okay, maybe it wasn’t IIM, maybe it was a slightly less known B-School, but the name isn’t important. What's important is that I now know all the buzzwords and can confidently use terms like "synergy" and "vertical integration" in everyday conversation. People are totally impressed, trust me. (Okay, maybe only my grandma is.) My CAT score was a decent 90 percentile. It could have been worse, I suppose. I still don't know what half the stuff on the exam even meant.
normalised: And then, because I hadn't suffered enough, I decided to prepone my M-B-A from I-I-M-C. Okay, maybe it wasn’t I-I-M, maybe it was a slightly less known B-School, but the name isn’t important. What's important is that I now know all the buzzwords and can confidently use terms like "synergy" and "vertical integration" in everyday conversation. People are totally impressed, trust me. (Okay, maybe only my grandma is.) My C-A-T score was a decent ninety percentile. It could have been worse, I suppose. I still don't know what half the stuff on the exam even meant.

unnormalised: But here's the kicker: All those certificates, degrees, and shiny accolades? They’re great for getting your foot in the door. They can get you that HR interview! But they don't guarantee success. What really matters is how you apply what you’ve learned (or at least pretended to learn) in the real world. I wish I could’ve spent more time working on that presentation but I spent way too long trying to prepone the date.
normalised: But here's the kicker: All those certificates, degrees, and shiny accolades? They’re great for getting your foot in the door. They can get you that H-R interview! But they don't guarantee success. What really matters is how you apply what you’ve learned (or at least pretended to learn) in the real world. I wish I could’ve spent more time working on that presentation but I spent way too long trying to prepone the date.

unnormalised: My point being? Don’t take the marks too seriously. Enjoy the ride (even when it feels like a rollercoaster of impending doom). And remember, the most valuable lessons aren’t always found in textbooks or on exam papers. Sometimes, they’re learned from the instant noodles, the late-night study sessions, and the occasional existential crisis.
normalised: My point being? Don’t take the marks too seriously. Enjoy the ride (even when it feels like a rollercoaster of impending doom). And remember, the most valuable lessons aren’t always found in textbooks or on exam papers. Sometimes, they’re learned from the instant noodles, the late-night study sessions, and the occasional existential crisis.

unnormalised: So, there you have it. A slightly embellished, mildly sarcastic, and completely honest account of my academic adventures. May your journey be filled with less stress, more success, and an abundance of chai. And maybe a good chiropractor. You’ll need it.
normalised: So, there you have it. A slightly embellished, mildly sarcastic, and completely honest account of my academic adventures. May your journey be filled with less stress, more success, and an abundance of chai. And maybe a good chiropractor. You’ll need it.

unnormalised: Now, if you'll excuse me, I have to go practice my "synergy" skills. Wish me luck! The performance target of 110% looms.
normalised: Now, if you'll excuse me, I have to go practice my "synergy" skills. Wish me luck! The performance target of one hundred and ten percent looms.
